info.description:
This is the base API for the ctrlX Data Layer access on ctrlX OS systems
  • Click 'Authorize' to open the 'Available authorizations' dialog.
  • Enter 'username' and 'password'. The 'Client credentials location' selector together with the 'client_id' and 'client_secret' fields as well as the 'Bearer' section can be ignored.
  • Click 'Authorize' and then 'Close' to close the 'Available authorizations' dialog.
  • Try out those GET, PUT, ... operations you're interested in.
info.title: ctrlX OS - Data Layer API

tags.name: Remotes

delete.description: Execute a delete operation on a node. Not every node is deletable.

parameters.description: The path is a string which contains the full access path in the data layer tree. The sub elements in the path are separated by '/'. To query the root node use '/' as path.
parameters.name: Path

200.description: Node deleted successfully

401.description: Not authorized to access this resource

500.description: Something unexpected happened on the server

delete.summary: Execute a delete operation on a node

get.description: Returns the data, browse-information or metadata of a requested node. Depends on the query parameter.

parameters.description: The path is a string which contains the full access path in the data layer tree. The sub elements in the path are separated by '/'. To query the root node use '/' as path.
parameters.name: Path

200.description: A JSON object or binary string containing the data, browseinfo or metadata of a requested node, depends on the query parameter.

400.description: The request is incomplete or malformed

401.description: Not authorized to access this resource

500.description: Something unexpected happened on the server

get.description:
Create a new subscription and starts server send event (SSE) stream. You can specify a bunch of paths to be observed for changes.

Unfortunately, SSE is not compatible to OpenAPI specs and can therefore not be properly specified within this API description. An SSE event contains three parts separated by linebreaks: event, id and data. Different events are separated by empty lines. The event field can be one of these types: keepalive, update, browse, metadata, error. The data field is populated with the JSON object defined below.

At startup you will get initial events for each node. Afterwards you will only get events if the value of the node changes.

parameters.description: Comma sepearted list of nodes
parameters.name: nodes

parameters.description: Publish interval for notifications. Internal poll interval.
parameters.name: publishIntervalMs

200.description: SSE Event stream

401.description: Not authorized to access this resource

500.description: Something unexpected happened on the server

get.summary: Create a new subscription and starts server send event (SSE) stream.

post.description:
Create a new subscription. You can later make GET request on this created subscription to start the subscription. If subscription is not used within one minute, subscription will be deleted automatically. You can start a created subscription multiple times.

To create a subscription in this way allows to setup more complex settings within the subscription (queueing, data change filter, ...).

nodes.description: list of nodes to subscribe to

requestBody.description: The data for the new subscription

200.description: Node successfully created

400.description: The request is incomplete or malformed

401.description: Not authorized to access this resource

500.description: Something unexpected happened on the server

post.summary: Create a new subscription as separate resource

delete.description: Deletes an existing subscription. A subscription can only be deleted if there are no open SSE connections for this SubscriptionName.

parameters.description: The SubscriptionName is a string which contains the identification of the subscription.
parameters.name: SubscriptionName

200.description: Subscription successfully deleted

400.description: The request is incomplete or malformed

401.description: Not authorized to access this resource

409.description: The request could not be completed due to a conflict with the current state of the target resource

500.description: Something unexpected happened on the server

get.description:
Starts a server send event stream (SSE) for a given subscription. You have to create this subscription before.

Unfortunately, SSE is not compatible to OpenAPI specs and can therefore not be properly specified within this API description. An SSE event contains three parts separated by linebreaks: event, id and data. Different events are separated by empty lines. The event field can be one of these types: keepalive, update, browse, metadata, error. The data field is populated with the JSON object defined below.

At startup you will get initial events for each node. Afterwards you will only get events if the value of the node changes.

parameters.description: The SubscriptionName is a string which contains the identification of the subscription.
parameters.name: SubscriptionName

200.description: SSE Event stream

401.description: Not authorized to access this resource

500.description: Something unexpected happened on the server

get.summary: Starts a server send event stream (SSE) on a given subscription

put.description: Change node list of existing subscription. All opened SSE connections for this subscription are changed.

parameters.description: The SubscriptionName is a string which contains the identification of the subscription.
parameters.name: SubscriptionName

200.description: Subscription successfully changed

400.description: The request is incomplete or malformed

401.description: Not authorized to access this resource

500.description: Something unexpected happened on the server

put.summary: Change node list of existing subscription.

timestamp.description: Timestamp of request of this entry

State.description: Current State of the framework / application

Task.description: Definition of a ctrlX scheduler task

type.description: The type of the returned value

Problem.description: This document defines a "problem detail" as a way  to carry machine-readable details of errors in a  HTTP response to avoid the need to define new error  response formats for HTTP APIs.

type.description:
A URI reference [RFC3986] that identifies the problem type. 
This specification encourages that, when dereferenced, 
it provide human-readable documentation for the problem type 
(e.g., using HTML [W3C.REC-html5-20141028]). When this member 
is not present, its value is assumed to be "about:blank".

title.description:
A short, human-readable summary of the problem type. 
It SHOULD NOT change from occurrence to occurrence of the problem, 
except for purposes of localization (e.g., using proactive content 
negotiation; see [RFC7231], Section 3.4).
title.example: You do not have enough credit.

status.description:
The HTTP status code ([RFC7231], Section 6) generated by the 
origin server for this occurrence of the problem.

detail.description: A human-readable explanation specific to this occurrence of the problem.
detail.example: Your current balance is 30, but that costs 50.

instance.description:
A URI reference that identifies the specific occurrence of the problem.
It may or may not yield further information if dereferenced.

code.description:
An error code issued by the system that caused the original problem.
This code can be used to track down the root cause of the error.

mainDiagnosisCode.description:
The main diagnosis code is issued by the system that caused the problem.
This code can be used to track down the root cause and source of the error.
It can be used to search in the documentation for a solution.
It SHOULD NOT change from occurrence to occurrence of the same problem.

detailedDiagnosisCode.description:
The detailed diagnosis code issued by the system that caused the problem.
This code can be used to track down the detailed cause and source of the error.
It can be used to search in the documentation for a solution.
The detailed diagnosis code gives additional information about the cause of the error.
It SHOULD NOT change from occurrence to occurrence of the same problem.

dynamicDescription.description:
A dynamic description gives detailed information about the occurrence of a problem.
It can change between different occurrences of the same error.

severity.description: Severity of a problem as defined RFC5424 of the Syslog standard, see https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5424

links.description:
Collection of links to fix the problem. E.g. links to online user manual,
to an online community (using tags) or a developer chat (e.g. Slack).

type.description: The type of the returned value
The type of the returned value
The type of the returned value

id.description: User identification for subscribtion. Use it update and dispose the old subscription

keepaliveInterval.description: keepalive in milli seconds for subscription time in seconds the subscriptions

publishInterval.description: time in milli seconds for upper limit of publish messages to not get flooded with new messages

errorInterval.description: time in milli seconds to re-read data if an error was received for a node

schema.description: reference to flatbuffer type in datalayer (only if type is "object")

SubscriptionNodeList.description: list of nodes to subscribe to

metadata.description: Describes the contents of the node data

Reference.description: References to the other nodes in the datalayer tree

total.description: total size of memory in bytes

free.description: free size of memory in bytes

used.description: used size of memory in bytes

biggestFree.description: biggest free chunk of memory in bytes

syncCounter.description: now often was the nvram synced

sizeBytes.description: Size in bytes of memory area

type.description: The type of the returned value
The type of the returned value
The type of the returned value

id.description: User identification for subscribtion. Use it update and dispose the old subscription

keepaliveInterval.description: keepalive in milli seconds for subscription time in seconds the subscriptions

publishInterval.description: time in milli seconds for upper limit of publish messages to not get flooded with new messages

errorInterval.description: time in milli seconds to re-read data if an error was received for a node

samplingInterval.description: sample time in  seconds for minimum sampling of data - currently only multiples of 1000 are supported

comm_datalayer_QueueBehaviour.description: The queing strategy. Decided what data should be sent or disarded when the queue runs full before it could be sent.

schema.description: reference to flatbuffer type in datalayer (only if type is "object")

serverIdlePingTimeout.description: after this time send a ping to not used provider is send to test if provider is still alive

serverWaitResponseTimeout.description: after this time a response from provider is expected - if there is no answer a provider is assumed to be dead --> kick provider out of routing
